Chapter 3: The Chapter on Pure Conduct
Bodhisattva KÄÅ›yapa said:
As the Buddha, the World-Honored One, said to ÅšÄriputra:
'What the world knows, I also know;
What the world does not know, I also know all.'
What is the meaning of this?
Good man!
All worldly people do not know, see, or realize the Buddha-nature;
If there are those who know, see, or realize the Buddha-nature, they are not called worldly people, but are called bodhisattvas.

Worldly people also do not know, see, or realize the twelve divisions of the canon, the twelve links of dependent arising, the four inversions, the four truths, the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, anuttara-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi, and great parinirvÄá¹‡a;
If there are those who know, see, or realize them, they are not called worldly people, but are called bodhisattvas.
Good man!
This is called what the world does not know, see, or perceive.
What is meant by what the world knows, sees, and perceives?
It refers to:

BrahmÄ, ÄªÅ›vara, Aá¹£á¹­Ävakra, nature, time, atoms, Dharma and non-Dharma as the creators, the beginning and end of the world, the two views of annihilationism and eternalism, and claiming that the first dhyÄna up to neither-perception-nor-non-perception is nirvÄá¹‡a.
Good son!
This is called what the world knows, sees, and perceives.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas know, see, and perceive such things.
If bodhisattvas, having known, seen, and perceived in this way, were to say they do not know, see, or perceive, this would be false.
Falsehood is then a fault, and due to this fault, one would fall into hell.
Good son!
If men, women, renunciants, or brahmins say:
'There is no path, enlightenment, or nirvÄá¹‡a.
You should know that such people are called icchantikas, the retinue of Mara, and those who slander the Dharma.
Slandering the Dharma in this way is called slandering all Buddhas. Such people are not called worldly, nor are they called non-worldly.
At that time, upon hearing this, Kasyapa praised the Buddha in verse, saying:
Out of great compassion for sentient beings, I now take refuge in you;
You skillfully extract all poisonous arrows, thus you are called the Great Physician King.
The treatments of worldly physicians, although effective, may recur;
The treatments of the Tathagata, once effective, will never recur.
The Tathagata uses the nectar-like medicine to bestow upon all sentient beings;
Once sentient beings have taken it, they neither die nor are reborn.
The Tathagata now expounds the Mahayana Nirvana for us;
Sentient beings who hear the secret treasury will attain non-arising and non-extinction.
Having spoken this verse, KÄÅ›yapa Bodhisattva addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha has said:
'All worldly beings are unable to know, see, or realize, but bodhisattvas can know, see, and realize.' If bodhisattvas are worldly beings, then one cannot say:
'Worldly beings are unable to know, see, or realize,' yet bodhisattvas can know, see, and realize. If they are not worldly beings, what are their distinguishing characteristics?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
Bodhisattvas are both worldly beings and not worldly beings.
Those who are unable to know, see, or realize are called worldly beings;
those who can know, see, and realize are not called worldly beings.
As for your question about their distinguishing characteristics, I will now explain.
Good man!

Whether male or female, if they first hear this Nirvana Sutra and immediately give rise to reverence and faith, and arouse the mind of supreme perfect enlightenment, they are then called worldly bodhisattvas.
All worldly people do not know, see, or realize. Such bodhisattvas are also the same as worldly people, not knowing, seeing, or realizing.
Bodhisattvas, having heard this Nirvana Sutra, know that there are things in the world that are not known, seen, or realized, which should be known, seen, and realized by bodhisattvas.
Having known this matter, they immediately contemplate:
How should I skillfully cultivate and practice, so as to know, see, and realize?
They think to themselves:
Only by deeply cultivating pure precepts can I do so.
Good man!
At that time, the bodhisattvas, due to these causes and conditions, in all their future lives, their precepts will always be pure.
Good man!
Because the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's precepts are pure, wherever he is born he is always without arrogance, wrong views, or doubts, and never says:
'The TathÄgata ultimately enters nirvÄá¹‡a.'
This is called the bodhisattva's practice of pure precepts.
Having already purified the precepts, next cultivate concentration.
Because of cultivating concentration, wherever one is born one correctly remembers without forgetting, namely:

All sentient beings have buddha-nature, the twelve divisions of the canon, the eternal, bliss, self, and purity of the buddhas, all bodhisattvas abiding in the Vaipulya MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra, and all see buddha-nature.
Such matters are remembered without forgetting.
Because of cultivating concentration, one attains the eleven kinds of emptiness. This is called the bodhisattva's cultivation of pure concentration.
Having already perfected the precepts and concentration, next cultivate pure wisdom.

By cultivating wisdom, one does not initially cling to the notion that the body contains a self, that the self contains a body, that this body is the self, or that the body is not the self. This is called the bodhisattva's cultivation of pure wisdom.
By cultivating wisdom, the precepts one upholds become firm and unmoving.
Good man!
It is like Mount Sumeru, which is not swayed by the four winds;
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are also like this, not swayed by the four inversions.
Good man!
When the bodhisattva then knows, sees, and realizes that the precepts they uphold are unmoving, this is called the bodhisattva's knowledge, vision, and realization that is not of the world.
Good man!
The bodhisattva sees that the precepts they uphold are firm and unmoving, and their mind is without regret;
Because there is no regret, the mind obtains joy;ğŸ”½Because the mind obtains joy, it obtains blissful pleasure;
Because it obtains blissful pleasure, the mind then becomes at ease;
Because the mind is at ease, it obtains unwavering concentration;
Because they attain the immovable samÄdhi, they attain true knowledge and insight;
Because of true knowledge and insight, they become disgusted with saá¹ƒsÄra;
Because they become disgusted with saá¹ƒsÄra, they attain liberation;
Because they attain liberation, they clearly see the Buddha-nature.
This is called the knowledge, seeing, and realization of the bodhisattvas, not of the world.
Good man!
This is called what the world does not know, see, or realize, but which the bodhisattvas know, see, and realize.
KÄÅ›yapa said again:
How do the bodhisattvas cultivate and uphold pure precepts, without regret or resentment, and clearly see the Buddha-nature?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
The precepts of the world are not called pure.
Why is this?
Because the precepts of the world are for the sake of existence, their nature is unstable, and they are not ultimate, so they cannot be widely practiced for all sentient beings.
For this reason, they are called impure;
Because they are impure, there is a mind of regret and resentment;
Because of remorse and regret, the mind has no joy;ğŸ”½Because there is no joy, there is no delight;ğŸ”½Because there is no delight, there is no peace;
Because there is no peace, there is no unshakable concentration;ğŸ”½Because there is no unshakable concentration, there is no true knowledge and insight;
Because there is no true knowledge and insight, there is no disgust;
Because there is no disgust, there is no liberation;
Because there is no liberation, the Buddha-nature is not seen;
Because the Buddha-nature is not seen, one is ultimately unable to attain great parinirvÄá¹‡a.
This is called the impurity of worldly precepts.
Good son!

The pure precepts of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are because precepts are not precepts, not for the sake of existence, ultimately for the sake of concentration, and for the sake of sentient beings. This is called the purity of the bodhisattva precepts.
Good son!
Although bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas do not wish to give rise to a mind of remorse in the pure precepts, a mind of remorse naturally arises.
Good man!
It is like a person holding a bright mirror, not expecting to see their face, yet the reflection of their face appears.
It is also like a farmer planting in good fields, not expecting the sprouts to grow, yet the sprouts grow by themselves.
It is also like lighting a lamp, not expecting to dispel the darkness, yet the darkness is dispelled by itself.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas upholding the pure precepts and giving rise to a mind of remorse and regret is also like this.
Because of the pure precepts, the mind attains joy.
Good man!
It is like a person with a beautiful face who sees their own face and gives rise to joy;
one who upholds the pure precepts is also like this.
Good man!
A person who breaks the precepts sees the impurity of the precepts and does not give rise to joy.
It is like a person with a disfigured body who sees their own face and does not give rise to joy;
a person who breaks the precepts is also like this.
Good man!

It is like two women with cows to milk, one with a pot of curd, the other with a pot of juice, both going to the city to sell them, stumbling on the road and breaking both pots, one rejoicing, the other sorrowful.
The same is true of those who keep the precepts and those who break them. Those who keep the pure precepts are joyful in their hearts.
Because the mind is joyful, one then contemplates:
The Buddhas and Tathagatas speak of nirvana.
Those who are able to keep the pure precepts will attain nirvana.
Since I now cultivate such pure precepts, I should also attain it.
For this reason, the mind is delighted.
KÄÅ›yapa said again:
Joy and pleasure, what is the difference?
Good man!
When the Bodhisattva-MahÄsattva does not do evil, it is called joy;
Keeping the precepts with a pure mind is called pleasure.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas regard saá¹ƒsÄra as joy;
Seeing great nirvÄá¹‡a is called bliss.
Inferior is called joy;
Superior is called bliss.
Separating from worldly common dharmas is called joy;
Attaining uncommon dharmas is called bliss.
Because of the purity of precepts, the body is light and soft, and the mouth is free from coarse faults.
At that time, the bodhisattva sees, hears, smells, tastes, touches, or knows without any evil;
Because of being without evil, the mind attains peace;
Because of peace, one attains tranquil concentration;
Because of attaining tranquil concentration, one attains true knowledge and insight;
Because of true knowledge and insight, one becomes disgusted with saá¹ƒsÄra;
Because of being disgusted with saá¹ƒsÄra, one attains liberation;
Because of attaining liberation, one sees the Buddha-nature;
Because of seeing the Buddha-nature, one attains great nirvÄá¹‡a.
This is called the bodhisattva's pure observance of precepts, not worldly precepts.
Why is it so?
Good man!
The pure precepts that bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas receive are assisted by five dharmas.
What are the five?
First, faith; second, shame; third, remorse; fourth, good and virtuous friends; fifth, revering and respecting the precepts.
Because one is free from the five hindrances, one's views are pure.
Because one is free from the five views, one's mind is free from doubts and entanglements.

Because one is free from the five doubts - namely, doubting the Buddha, doubting the Dharma, doubting the Saá¹ƒgha, doubting the precepts, and doubting not being heedless - at that time one attains the five faculties, namely faith, mindfulness, vigor, concentration, and wisdom.
Because one attains the five faculties, one attains the five kinds of nirvÄá¹‡a, namely liberation from form up to liberation from consciousness.
This is called the bodhisattva's pure observance of precepts, not of the world.
Good man!
This is what the world does not know, see, or realize, but it is what the bodhisattvas know, see, and realize.
Good sons!
If my disciples uphold, recite, copy, and explain the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra, but there are those who violate the precepts, and if others rebuke, despise, and insult them, saying:
'If the secret treasury of the Buddha, the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra, has power, then why does it allow you to violate the precepts you have received?
If people uphold this NirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra but violate the precepts, then know that this sÅ«tra has no power.
If it has no power, then even if one recites it, it will be of no benefit.'
Because of despising the NirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra in this way, it will cause countless sentient beings to fall into hell.
Those who uphold this sÅ«tra but violate the precepts are the bad friends of sentient beings, not my disciples, but the retinue of MÄra.

For such people, I also do not allow them to uphold this canon. It is better for them not to receive, uphold, or cultivate it, rather than to receive, uphold, or cultivate it while violating the precepts.
Good man!

If my disciples receive, uphold, recite, copy, and expound the Nirvana Sutra, they should be upright in body and mind, and should not be frivolous or agitated in movement - the body is frivolous, and the mind is agitated;

The mind that seeks existence is called agitation, and the body creating various karmic actions is called frivolity. If my disciples seek existence and create karmic actions, they should not receive and uphold this Mahayana canon, the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra.
If there are those who receive and uphold this sÅ«tra in this way, people will despise and criticize them, saying:
'If the secret treasury of the Buddha, the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra, has power, then why does it cause you to seek existence and create karmic actions?'
If those who uphold the sÅ«tra seek existence and create karma, know that this sÅ«tra has no majestic power.
If it has no majestic power, even if one upholds it, it will be of no benefit.
Because of slighting and defaming the Nirvana Sutra, it will cause countless sentient beings to fall into hell.
Upholding this sÅ«tra, seeking existence and creating karma, is the bad spiritual friend of sentient beings, not my disciple, but a follower of MÄra.
Furthermore, good man!

If my disciples uphold, recite, copy, and expound the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra, do not speak at inappropriate times, do not speak in inappropriate countries, do not speak without being requested, do not speak with a light mind, do not speak everywhere, do not speak while praising oneself, do not speak while slighting others, do not speak while extinguishing the Buddha Dharma, do not speak while fanning worldly dharmas.
Good man!
If my disciples uphold this sÅ«tra and expound it at the wrong time, even if they expound worldly dharmas with great fervor, people will despise and ridicule them, saying:
'If the secret treasury of the Buddha, the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra, has power, why does it allow you to expound at the wrong time, even expound worldly dharmas with great fervor?
If those who uphold the sÅ«tra speak like this, know that this sÅ«tra has no power.
If it has no power, even if you uphold it, it will be of no benefit.'
Because of despising and defaming the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra, they cause countless sentient beings to fall into hell.
Upholding this sÅ«tra and expounding it at the wrong time, even expounding worldly dharmas with great fervor, is the bad spiritual friend of sentient beings, not my disciple, but a follower of MÄra.
Good man!

If one wishes to uphold it, expound the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a, expound the Buddha-nature, expound the secret treasury of the TathÄgata, expound the MahÄyÄna, expound the Vaipulya sÅ«tras, expound the ÅšrÄvakayÄna, expound the PratyekabuddhayÄna, expound liberation, or see the Buddha-nature, one should first purify one's body.
Because the body is pure, there will be no reproach;
Because there is no reproach, it causes countless people to give rise to pure faith in the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a;

Because faith arises, they will revere this sÅ«tra. If they hear a verse, a sentence, a single word, or if they expound the Dharma, they will be able to give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment.
One should know that such a person is a true and good spiritual friend of sentient beings, not an evil friend, a disciple of mine, not an attendant of MÄra.
This is called a bodhisattva who is not of the world.
Good son!
This is what the world does not know, see, or realize, but the bodhisattva knows, sees, and realizes.
Moreover, good man!
How is it that the world does not know, see, or realize, but the bodhisattva knows, sees, and realizes?
It refers to the six recollections.
What are the six?
Recollecting the Buddha, recollecting the Dharma, recollecting the Saá¹…gha, recollecting the precepts, recollecting generosity, and recollecting the heavens.

What is recollecting the Buddha?

unchanging, endowed with the ten powers and four fearlessnesses, roaring the great lion's roar, known as
the great Å›ramaá¹‡a, the great brÄhmaá¹‡a, the great pure one, ultimately reaching the other shore, without

accomplished. The king of human elephants, the king of human bulls, the king of human dragons, the human

donor, the great Dharma teacher.ğŸ”½Because of knowing the Dharma, he is called a great Dharma teacher;

Because he expounds the middle way, he is called a great Dharma master.
What is meant by TathÄgata?
It means that what the Buddhas of the past spoke does not change.
Why does it not change?
The Buddhas of the past spoke the twelve divisions of the canon in order to deliver sentient beings;
The TathÄgata is also like this, and therefore he is called the TathÄgata.
The World-Honored Buddhas come to the great nirvÄá¹‡a from the six pÄramitÄs, the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, and the eleven kinds of emptiness;

The World-Honored Buddhas, for the sake of sentient beings, skillfully reveal the three vehicles, with lifespans that are immeasurable and incalculable;
The TathÄgata is also like this, and therefore the Buddha is called the TathÄgata.
What is meant by Arhat?
Worldly dharmas are all called enemies, because the Buddha should destroy them, he is called an Arhat.

As for the four demons, they are the enemies of the bodhisattvas. The buddhas and tathÄgatas, when they were bodhisattvas, were able to destroy the four demons with wisdom, and for this reason they are called the Worthy One.
Furthermore, the Worthy One is called one who is far removed.
When one is a bodhisattva, one should be far removed from immeasurable afflictions, and for this reason he is called the Worthy One.
Furthermore, the Worthy One is called one who delights.

The buddhas of the past, when they were bodhisattvas, although for immeasurable asaá¹ƒkhyeya eons they endured various sufferings and afflictions for the sake of sentient beings, they never had any displeasure but were always delighted.
The TathÄgata is also like this, and for this reason he is called the Worthy One.

Moreover, the Worthy One is one whom all humans and gods should make offerings with various kinds of incense, flowers, necklaces, banners, canopies, and music, and for this reason he is called the Worthy One.
What is meant by 'right and universal knowledge'?
Right means not being inverted;
universal knowledge means being thoroughly enlightened regarding the four inversions.
Moreover, right means practicing austerities;
Omniscience means knowing that the practice of austerities definitely has the result of suffering.
Moreover, right means in the world;

Moreover, right means countable, measurable, and comparable;
omniscience means uncountable, immeasurable, and incomparable.
Therefore, the Buddha is called the Right and Omniscient One.
Good man!
The Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas have omniscience and also do not have omniscience.
Why is it so?
Omniscience means the five aggregates, twelve sense fields, and eighteen elements. The Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas also attain omniscience, which is called omniscience.
Why is it said to be not omniscience?
Good man!
If the Two Vehicles contemplate a single aggregate of form for immeasurable eons, they cannot fully understand it. For this reason, the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas do not have omniscience.
What is meant by 'one who has perfected bright conduct'?
'Bright' refers to attaining immeasurable good fruits;
'Conduct' refers to feet;
'Good fruits' refers to anuttara-samyak-sambodhi.
'Feet' refers to precepts and wisdom.
Relying on the feet of precepts and wisdom to attain anuttara-samyak-sambodhi, therefore it is called 'one who has perfected bright conduct.'
Moreover, 'bright' refers to spells;
'Conduct' refers to auspiciousness;
'Feet' refers to fruits.
Good man!
This is called the meaning in the world.
Spells are called liberation;
Auspiciousness is called anuttara-samyak-sambodhi;
Fruits are called great parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Therefore, it is called 'one who has perfected bright conduct.'
Moreover, 'bright' refers to light;
'Conduct' refers to karma;
'Feet' refers to fruits.
Good man!
This is called the meaning in the world.
Light refers to non-negligence;
Action refers to the six perfections;
The fruit refers to supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Moreover, illumination refers to the three illuminations:
First, the illumination of bodhisattvas; second, the illumination of buddhas; third, the illumination of non-illumination.
The illumination of bodhisattvas is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ; the illumination of buddhas is the buddha eye; the illumination of non-illumination is ultimate emptiness.
Practice refers to cultivating various wholesome actions for the sake of sentient beings for immeasurable eons.
Feet refer to clearly seeing buddha-nature.
For this reason, it is called having the illumination of practice and virtue.
What is meant by 'well-gone'?
Well means high;
Gone means not high.
Good sons!
This is called the meaning of the mundane world.
High refers to supreme, perfect enlightenment;
Not high refers to the mind of the TathÄgata.
Good sons!
If the mind is lofty, it is not called the TathÄgata.
Therefore, the TathÄgata is called the Well-Gone.
Moreover, well is called a good friend;
gone is the fruit of a good friend.
Good man!
This is called the meaning in the world.
A good friend is the initial arousal of the mind;
The fruit is called great parinirvÄá¹‡a.
The TathÄgata does not abandon the initially aroused mind to attain great parinirvÄá¹‡a. Therefore, the TathÄgata is called the Well-Gone.
Moreover, well is called good;
gone is called existent.
Good man!
This is called the meaning in the world.
Good is called seeing the Buddha-nature;
Existent is called great parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Good man!
The nature of parinirvÄá¹‡a is truly non-existent. The World-Honored Buddhas, because of the world, say it exists.
Good man!
It is like worldly people who truly have no children, yet say they have children;
In reality there is no path, yet it is said there is a path;
Nirvana is also like this. Because of the world, it is said to exist.
The buddhas, the world-honored ones, attain great nirvana, and are therefore called the Well-Gone.
Good sons!
What is meant by 'knower of the world'?
Good sons!
The world refers to the five aggregates;
Knowing means understanding.
The buddhas, the world-honored ones, well understand the five aggregates, and are therefore called knowers of the world.
Moreover, the world refers to the five desires;
Knowing means non-attachment.
Not being attached to the five desires, they are called knowers of the world.

Moreover, as for knowers of the world, in the innumerable asaá¹ƒkhyeya worlds in the east, all Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas do not know, see, or understand, but the buddhas fully know, see, and understand;
The same is true in the south, west, north, the four intermediate directions, above, and below.
Therefore, the buddhas are called knowers of the world.
Moreover, the world refers to all ordinary beings;
understanding means knowing the good and evil causes and effects of all ordinary beings.
This is not something that Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas can know, only the Buddha can know it, and therefore the Buddha is called the knower of the world.
Moreover, the world is called a lotus flower;
understanding means being unstained.
Good man!
This is called the meaning of the world.
The lotus flower is the TathÄgata;
being unstained means that the TathÄgata is not tainted by the eight worldly dharmas of the world.
Therefore, the Buddha is called the knower of the world.
Moreover, the knower of the world refers to buddhas and bodhisattvas being called the knower of the world.
Why is it so?
Because buddhas and bodhisattvas see the world, they are called the knower of the world.
Good man!
Just as because of food one obtains life, food is called life,
buddhas and bodhisattvas are also like this, because they see the world, they are called the knower of the world.
What is meant by 'unsurpassed person'?ğŸ”½An unsurpassed person is one who has eliminated all afflictions.
One who has nothing to eliminate is called an unsurpassed person.
The buddhas, the world-honored ones, have no afflictions, so there is nothing to eliminate. Therefore, the Buddha is called an unsurpassed person.
Moreover, an unsurpassed person is one who is free from disputes.
An unsurpassed person is one who is free from disputes.
The TathÄgata is free from disputes. Therefore, the Buddha is called an unsurpassed person.
Moreover, an unsurpassed person is one whose words cannot be destroyed.
An unsurpassed person is one whose words cannot be destroyed.
The words of the TathÄgata cannot be destroyed by any sentient being. Therefore, the Buddha is called an unsurpassed person.
Moreover, an unsurpassed person is one who is the highest seat.
An unsurpassed person is one who is the unsurpassed seat.
Among the buddhas of the three times, there is no one who surpasses him. Therefore, the Buddha is called an unsurpassed person.ğŸ”½The highest is called new.
A person is called old.
The essence of the great nirvÄá¹‡a of the buddhas of the past, present, and future is neither new nor old, and for this reason the Buddha is called the unsurpassed person.
What is meant by 'tamer of men'?
Having been a man oneself, one also tames men.
Good man!
The TathÄgata is truly neither a man nor not a man.
Because he tames men, the TathÄgata is called a man.
Good man!
All men and women who possess the four dharmas are called men.
What are the four?
First, a good friend; second, being able to listen to the Dharma; third, contemplating the meaning; fourth, practicing in accordance with the teachings.
Good man!
If men and women possess these four dharmas, they are called men.
Good man!
If there are men who do not have these four dharmas, they cannot be called men.
Why is this?
Although their bodies are men, their actions are the same as animals.
The TathÄgata tames men and women, and for this reason he is called the Buddha, the Tamer of Men.
Moreover, good man!
There are four kinds of charioteers:
The first touches the hair, the second touches the skin, the third touches the flesh, and the fourth touches the bones, and they all do as the charioteer intends.

The TathÄgata is also like this. He tames sentient beings with four kinds of dharmas:ğŸ”½First, for those who are born, he speaks and causes them to accept the Buddha's words, like touching their hair and doing as the charioteer intends;

Second, for those who are born and grow old, he speaks and causes them to accept the Buddha's words, like touching their hair and skin and doing as the charioteer intends;ğŸ”½Third, for those who are born, grow old, and become ill, he speaks and causes them to accept the Buddha's words, like touching their hair, skin, and flesh and doing as the charioteer intends;

Fourth, for those who are born, grow old, become ill, and die, he speaks and causes them to accept the Buddha's words, like touching their hair, skin, flesh, and bones and doing as the charioteer intends.
Good man!
The charioteer tames horses without certainty, but the World-Honored One tames beings with certainty and never in vain. Therefore, the Buddha is called the Tamer of Men.
Why is he called the Teacher of Gods and Humans?
There are two kinds of teachers:
one teaches good, the other teaches evil.
Buddhas and Bodhisattvas always teach sentient beings with good dharmas.
What are the good dharmas?
They are the goodness of body, speech, and mind.
Buddhas and Bodhisattvas teach sentient beings, saying:
'Good men!
You should stay far away from unwholesome bodily actions.
Why is it so?
Because unwholesome bodily actions are to be abandoned and liberation is to be attained. Therefore, I teach you with this Dharma.
If unwholesome actions cannot be abandoned and liberation cannot be attained, I will never teach you to abandon them.'
If sentient beings fall into the three evil realms after abandoning unwholesome actions, it is impossible.
Because of this detachment, they attain supreme, perfect enlightenment and great nirvÄá¹‡a.
Therefore, the buddhas and bodhisattvas always use this Dharma to teach and transform sentient beings.
The same is true for speech and mind.
Therefore, the Buddha is called the unsurpassed teacher.
Furthermore, in the past he had not attained the Way, but now he has attained it, and he expounds the Way he has attained for the sake of sentient beings;
From the beginning he had not yet cultivated pure conduct, but now he has completed the cultivation, and he expounds what he has cultivated for the sake of sentient beings;
He himself destroys ignorance, and he also destroys ignorance for the sake of sentient beings;
He himself attains pure vision, and he also removes the blindness and confusion of sentient beings, enabling them to attain pure vision;
He himself understands the two truths, and he also expounds the two truths for the sake of sentient beings;
Having himself attained liberation, he also expounds the Dharma of liberation for the sake of sentient beings;
Having himself crossed the boundless great river of birth and death, he also enables sentient beings to all attain liberation;
Having attained fearlessness oneself, one also teaches sentient beings to be free from fear;
Having attained nirvana oneself, one also expounds the great nirvana for sentient beings.
Therefore, the Buddha is called the unsurpassed teacher.
Heaven means daytime. In heaven, the daytime is long and the night is short, so it is called heaven.
Moreover, heaven means being free from sorrow and always experiencing bliss, so it is called heaven.
Moreover, heaven means lamplight, able to destroy darkness and become great illumination, so it is called heaven.
It is also because one can destroy evil karma and darkness, and attain wholesome karma to be born in the heavens, so it is called heaven.
Moreover, heaven means auspicious, because of being auspicious, it is called heaven.
Moreover, heaven means sun. The sun has light, so the sun is called heaven.
For this reason, it is called heaven.
Human means able to repay many kindnesses and righteousness.
Moreover, a human is one whose body and speech are gentle.
Moreover, a human is one who has pride.
Moreover, a human is one who can destroy pride.
Good man!
Although the Buddhas are the unsurpassed great teachers for all sentient beings, the sÅ«tras say they are teachers of gods and humans.
Why is this?
Good man!

Among all sentient beings, only gods and humans can give rise to the intention to achieve unsurpassable perfect enlightenment, can cultivate the ten wholesome courses of action, can attain the fruits of stream-entry, once-returning, non-returning, and arhatship, can attain pratyekabuddhahood, and can attain unsurpassable perfect enlightenment. Therefore, the Buddha is called the teacher of gods and humans.
What is meant by 'Buddha'?
A Buddha is one who is enlightened, who is self-awakened and able to awaken others.
Good man!
It is like a person who is aware of the presence of a thief, and the thief is unable to do anything.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are able to awaken to all immeasurable afflictions. Having awakened to them, they cause the afflictions to be powerless. Therefore, they are called Buddhas.
Because of this awakening, they do not give rise to birth, old age, sickness, or death. Therefore, they are called Buddhas.
As for BhagavÄn, bhagÄ means to destroy, and vÄn means afflictions.
Because he is able to destroy afflictions, he is called BhagavÄn.

Moreover, because he is able to accomplish all wholesome dharmas, because he is able to skillfully understand the meanings of all dharmas, because he has great merits and virtues that cannot be surpassed, because his great fame pervades the ten directions, because he is able to bestow great wisdom in various ways, and because he has for immeasurable asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas spit out the female organ,
Good man!

If men or women are able to think of the Buddha in this way, whether walking, standing, sitting, or lying down, whether day or night, whether in light or darkness, they will always be able to see the World-Honored Buddha without fail.
Good sons!
Why is it called the TathÄgata, the Worthy One, the Perfectly Enlightened One, up to the BhagavÄn, and why does he have such immeasurable merits and great fame?

Good sons!ğŸ”½Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas in the past, for innumerable asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas, respectfully served their parents, preceptors, teachers, and elders. For innumerable kalpas, they always practiced giving for the sake of sentient beings, upheld precepts, cultivated patience, diligently practiced vigor, and practiced meditation, wisdom, great kindness, great compassion, great joy, and great equanimity. For this reason, they now attain the thirty-two marks, the eighty minor marks, and the vajra body.

Moreover, bodhisattvas in the past, for innumerable asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas, cultivated the faculties of faith, mindfulness, vigor, concentration, and wisdom. They respectfully served and made offerings to their teachers and elders, always seeking the benefits of the Dharma, not the benefits of food.

If bodhisattvas uphold the twelve divisions of the scriptures, whether reading or reciting them, they always do so for the sake of sentient beings, enabling them to attain liberation, peace, and happiness, never for their own sake.
Why is this?
Because bodhisattvas always cultivate the mind of transcending the world, the mind of renouncing the household life, the mind of being free from conditioned activities,
the mind free from disputes and litigation, the mind free from defilements and impurities, the mind free from bondage, the mind free from attachment,
the mind free from concealment, the mind free from indeterminate thoughts, the mind free from thoughts of birth and death, the mind free from doubts and webs,
the mind free from greed and desire, the mind free from anger and hatred, the mind free from ignorance and delusion, the mind free from arrogance and conceit,
the mind free from turbidity and defilement, the mind free from afflictions, the mind free from suffering, the immeasurable mind, the vast mind,
the mind of space, the mind without thought, the mind without non-thought, the disciplined mind, the mind without protection,
the mind without concealment, the mind free from worldly thoughts, the mind always in concentration, the mind always in cultivation, the mind always in liberation,
a mind without retribution, a mind without wishes, a mind of good wishes, a mind without error, a mind of gentleness,

a mind of non-abiding, a mind of mastery, a mind without outflows, a mind of ultimate truth, a mind of non-retrogression, a mind of impermanence, a mind of uprightness, a mind without flattery or deceit, a mind of pure goodness,
a mind without much or little, a mind without solidity, a mind without ordinary beings, a mind without Å›rÄvakas, a mind without
pratyekabuddhas, a mind well-knowing, a mind knowing the realms, a mind knowing the arising of realms, a mind knowing the abiding of realms,
a mind of mastery over realms, therefore now attaining the ten powers, the four forms of fearlessness, great
compassion, the three establishments of mindfulness, permanence, bliss, self, and purity, therefore attaining the title of TathÄgata
up to BhagavÄn.
This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's mindfulness of the Buddha.
What is the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's mindfulness of the Dharma?
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplate the Dharma taught by the buddhas, which is most wonderful and supreme. Because of this Dharma, it enables sentient beings to attain present fruits.
Only this true Dharma has no time or season. It is seen by the Dharma eye, not by the flesh eye. However,
it cannot be compared with metaphors. It is unborn, unproduced, not abiding, not ceasing,
not beginning, not ending, unconditioned, innumerable. For those without a home, it creates a home;
for those without refuge, it creates a refuge; for those in darkness, it creates illumination; for those not yet reached the other shore, it enables them to reach the other shore;
for those without fragrance, it creates unobstructed fragrance. It is invisible, yet can be seen. It is immovable and unchanging,
neither long nor short. It permanently severs all pleasures and is the bliss of peace and security. It is ultimately subtle and wonderful,
not form, yet it severs form and is form. It is not consciousness, yet it severs consciousness and is consciousness.

It is also consciousness, not karma, not cutting off karma, not afflictions, not cutting off afflictions, not objects, not cutting offğŸ”½objects, yet also being objects, not realms, not cutting off realms, yet also being realms, not existence,
not cutting off existence, yet also being existence, not sense bases, not cutting off sense bases, yet also being sense bases,
not causes, not cutting off causes, yet also being causes, not effects, not cutting off effects, yet also being
effects, not empty, not real, not cutting off all that is real, yet also being real, not arising,
not ceasing, permanently cutting off arising and ceasing, yet also being cessation, not characteristics, not not characteristics, cutting off
all characteristics, yet also being characteristics, not teachings, not not teachings, yet also being the teacher,
not fear, not peace, cutting off all fears, yet also being peace, not patience, not not
patience, permanently cutting off impatience, yet also being patience, not cessation, not not cessation, cutting offğŸ”½one
It is also the summit of all dharmas, able to permanently sever all afflictions,
pure and without characteristics, eternally free from all characteristics, the ultimate abode of innumerable sentient beings,
able to extinguish all the raging fires of birth and death, the place where all Buddhas dwell, permanent,
unchanging.
This is called the bodhisattva's mindfulness of the Dharma.
What is meant by mindfulness of the Saá¹…gha?

The noble Saá¹…gha of Buddhas abides in accordance with the Dharma, accepts the upright Dharma, and practices in accordance with it. It cannot be seen, grasped, or destroyed, cannot be harmed, and is inconceivable.
It is the excellent field of merit for all sentient beings. Although it is a field of merit, it does not accept anything.

This is called mindfulness of the Saá¹…gha.
What is mindfulness of precepts?
Bodhisattvas contemplate:
There are precepts that are unbroken, unmutilated, undiminished, and unadulterated.
Although they have no form or color, they can be upheld and protected;
Although they are intangible, skillful means can be cultivated.
They can be fully possessed without fault, praised by buddhas and bodhisattvas, and are the cause of the great vehicle and great nirvana.
Good sons!

They are like the earth, a ship, a necklace, the great ocean, lye, a house, a sword, a bridge, a good doctor's wonderful medicine, agada medicine, a wish-fulfilling jewel, feet, eyes, parents, shade, which cannot be stolen, cannot be harmed, cannot be burned by fire, cannot be carried away by water, a great mountain staircase, the wonderful jeweled victory banner of buddhas and bodhisattvas.
If one abides in these precepts and attains the fruit of stream-entry, I also have a share, but I do not need it.
Why is it so?
If I attain this fruit of stream-entry, I will not be able to extensively deliver all sentient beings.
If I abide by this precept, I will attain supreme perfect enlightenment, and I will also have a share in it, which is what I desire.
Why is it so?
If I attain supreme perfect enlightenment, I will extensively expound the wonderful Dharma for the sake of sentient beings and act as their refuge.
This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's mindfulness of precepts.
What is mindfulness of giving?
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva deeply observes that this giving is the cause of supreme perfect enlightenment.
The buddhas and bodhisattvas closely cultivate such giving, and I also closely cultivate it in the same way.
If I do not give generously, I will not be able to adorn the fourfold assembly.
Although giving cannot ultimately sever afflictions, it can eliminate and destroy present afflictions.
Because of the causes and conditions of giving, he is always praised by sentient beings in the worlds of the ten directions, innumerable and boundless like the sands of the Ganges River.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who give food to sentient beings give them life. Because of this retribution, when they attain Buddhahood, it is eternal and unchanging.
Because of giving happiness, when they attain Buddhahood, they attain peace and happiness.
When bodhisattvas give, they seek wealth in accordance with the Dharma and do not harm others in giving. Therefore, when they attain Buddhahood, they attain pure nirvÄá¹‡a.
When bodhisattvas give, they cause sentient beings to obtain without seeking. Therefore, when they attain Buddhahood, they attain self-mastery.
Because of the causes and conditions of giving, they cause others to obtain strength. Therefore, when they attain Buddhahood, they obtain the ten powers.
Because of the causes and conditions of giving, they cause others to obtain speech. Therefore, when they attain Buddhahood, they attain the four unobstructed [abilities].

The buddhas and bodhisattvas cultivate this giving as a cause for nirvÄá¹‡a. I also cultivate giving in the same way as a cause for nirvÄá¹‡a. It is explained in detail in the Miscellaneous Flower [SÅ«tra].

If there is morality, learning, generosity, and wisdom, and one attains the abode of the Four Heavenly Kings up to attaining the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, I also have a share, but that is not what I desire.
Why is it so?
The abodes of the Four Heavenly Kings up to the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception are all impermanent.
Because of impermanence, there is birth, old age, sickness, and death.
For this reason, it is not what I desire.
It is like an illusion deceiving the ignorant, but the wise are not deluded or attached to it.

The illusory is the abodes of the Four Heavenly Kings up to the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, and the ignorant are all ordinary beings. I am not the same as the foolish ordinary beings.
I have heard that there is a supreme truth heaven, namely the buddhas and bodhisattvas, which is eternal and unchanging.
Because it abides eternally, it does not arise, does not age, does not become ill, and does not die.
I diligently seek the supreme truth heaven for the sake of sentient beings.
Why is this?
The supreme truth heaven can enable sentient beings to eliminate afflictions, just like a wish-fulfilling tree.
If I have faith and wisdom, then I will be able to attain this supreme truth heaven and will expound it extensively for the sake of sentient beings.
This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's mindfulness of the heavens.
Good son!
This is called the bodhisattva who is not of the world. This is what the world does not know, see, or realize, but it is what the bodhisattva knows, sees, and realizes.

If my disciples say that upholding, reciting, copying, and expounding the twelve divisions of the canon, as well as upholding, reciting, copying, and elaborately explaining the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra, are no different, that is not so.

For this reason, the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra is extremely marvelous, extremely special, and inconceivable.
Bodhisattva MahÄkÄÅ›yapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

The Buddha, the Dharma, and the Saá¹…gha are inconceivable, and the bodhisattvas, bodhi, and the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra are also inconceivable.
World-Honored One!
For what meaning does it again say that the bodhisattva is inconceivable?
Good man!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva has no teacher, yet he can give rise to the mind of enlightenment by himself;

Having given rise to the mind, he diligently cultivates and practices. Even if a great fire were to burn his body and head, he would never seek to be saved and abandon the mind of mindfulness of the Dharma.
Why is this?
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva always thinks to himself:

'For immeasurable asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas, I have either been in the hells, hungry ghosts, animals, human realm, or heavenly realm, being burned by the fires of the afflictions, and have never before attained a definitive Dharma. The definitive Dharma is precisely anuttara-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi.
For the sake of anuttara-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi, I will never spare my body, mind, and life.'
I am seeking supreme, perfect enlightenment. Even if my body were to be ground to dust, I would never abandon diligent effort.
Why is this?
Diligent effort is the cause of supreme, perfect enlightenment.'
Good sons!
In this way, the bodhisattva has not yet seen supreme, perfect enlightenment, yet is able to be so unconcerned with life and limb, let alone after seeing it.
Therefore, the bodhisattva is inconceivable.
Moreover, the inconceivable bodhisattva-mahÄsattva sees the immeasurable faults of birth and death that are not within the reach of the hearers and solitary realizers.
Although they know the immeasurable faults of birth and death, for the sake of sentient beings they experience suffering within it without giving rise to revulsion.
Therefore, they are also called inconceivable.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, for the sake of sentient beings, although they experience various sufferings in the hells, it is like the bliss of the third dhyÄna. Therefore, it is also called inconceivable.
Good son!
It is like a householder whose house catches fire.
The householder, having seen this, comes out of the house, while his children are still inside, not yet escaping the danger of the fire.
At that time, the householder definitely knows the harm of the fire, but for the sake of his children, he turns back to rescue them, not caring about the danger.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are also like this. Although they know that birth and death have many faults, for the sake of sentient beings, they dwell in it without aversion. Therefore, it is also called inconceivable.

Immeasurable sentient beings give rise to the aspiration for enlightenment, but seeing that birth and death have many faults, their minds immediately retreat and fall back, becoming Å›rÄvakas or pratyekabuddhas.

If there are people who say:
'I can swim across the great ocean.'
Is such a statement conceivable or not?
World-Honored One!
Such a statement may be conceivable or inconceivable.
Why is it so?
If a human being crosses it, it is inconceivable, but if an asura crosses it, it is conceivable.
Good man!
I do not speak of asuras, but only of humans.
World-Honored One!
Among humans, there are also those who are conceivable and those who are inconceivable.
World-Honored One!
Humans are also of two kinds:
First, the sages, and second, ordinary beings.
Ordinary beings are inconceivable, while sages are conceivable.
Good man!
I speak of ordinary beings, not sages.
World-Honored One!
If ordinary beings are truly inconceivable,
Good man!
Ordinary beings truly cannot cross the great ocean.
Thus, bodhisattvas can truly cross the great ocean of birth and death, and therefore they are also called inconceivable.
Good man!
If someone can hang Mount Sumeru with lotus root fibers, is that conceivable?
No, World-Honored One!
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas can in a single thought weigh all birth and death, and therefore they are also called inconceivable.
Good man!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, for innumerable asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas, have always contemplated the impermanence, no-self, no happiness, and no purity of saá¹ƒsÄra, and for the sake of sentient beings, they expound and explain permanence, happiness, self, and purity. Although they speak in this way, it is not a mistaken view. Therefore, it is also called inconceivable.

Just as a person can enter water without drowning and enter a great raging fire without being burned, such a thing is inconceivable.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are also like this. Although they dwell in saá¹ƒsÄra, they are not harmed by saá¹ƒsÄra. Therefore, it is also called inconceivable.
Good man!
There are three types of people, namely superior, middling, and inferior.
When an inferior person first enters the womb, he thinks:
'I am now in a latrine, a place where all impurities return, like among dead bodies, among many thorns, in a great dark place.'
When first emerging from the womb, they think:
'I am now leaving the toilet, leaving the place of many impurities, up to leaving the place of great darkness.'
Those of middling capacity think:
'I am now entering the forest of many trees, the pure river, the bedroom and house.'
When leaving, it is also like this.
Those of superior capacity think:
'I am ascending the palace, in the midst of flower groves, riding a horse, riding an elephant, climbing a high mountain.'
When leaving, it is also like this.

When the Bodhisattva Mahasattva first enters the womb, he knows he is entering the womb, knows he is staying while staying, and knows he is leaving when leaving. He never gives rise to thoughts of greed or anger, but has not yet attained the first stage of abiding, and for this reason it is also called inconceivable.
Good man!
Anuttara-samyak-sambodhi cannot really be compared to anything.
Good man!
The mind also cannot be compared to anything else, yet it can all be explained.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas have no teacher to consult and learn from, yet they are able to attain anuttara-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi.
Having attained this Dharma, their minds are not stingy, and they always expound it for sentient beings.
Therefore, it is also called inconceivable.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas have physical seclusion that is not verbal, have verbal seclusion that is not physical, and have both non-physical and non-verbal seclusion.
Physical seclusion refers to being free from killing, stealing, and sexual misconduct, which is called physical seclusion that is not verbal.
Verbal seclusion refers to being free from false speech, divisive speech, harsh speech, and meaningless speech, which is called verbal seclusion that is not physical.
Non-physical and non-verbal seclusion refers to being free from greed, hatred, and wrong views.
Good man!
This is called neither physical nor verbal, yet it is still far removed.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas do not see a single dharma that is the body, the activity, or the master of separation, yet there is still separation. For this reason, it is also called inconceivable;
the mouth is also like this.
Good man!
From the body, separate from the body; from the mouth, separate from the mouth; from wisdom, far removed, neither physical nor verbal.
Good man!
There truly is this wisdom, but it cannot cause the bodhisattva to be far removed.
Why is it so?
Good man!
There is not a single dharma that can destroy or create.
The nature of conditioned dharmas is to arise differently and cease differently, therefore this wisdom cannot be far removed.
Good man!

Wisdom cannot be destroyed, fire cannot burn it, water cannot rot it, wind cannot move it, earth cannot support it, birth cannot give rise to it, old age cannot age it, abiding cannot make it abide, destruction cannot destroy it, greed cannot make it greedy, anger cannot make it angry, delusion cannot make it deluded, because its conditioned nature arises differently and ceases differently.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas never give rise to the thought:
'I use this wisdom to destroy afflictions.'
And they do not say:
'I destroy afflictions.'
Although they say this, it is not false, and therefore it is also called inconceivable.
KÄÅ›yapa said again:
World-Honored One!

I now understand for the first time that bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are inconceivable, that the Buddha, the Dharma, the Saá¹…gha, the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra, those who uphold it, bodhi, and nirvÄá¹‡a are inconceivable.
World-Honored One!
How long will the unsurpassed Buddha Dharma remain in the world before it perishes?
Good man!
If the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra contains these five practices:
namely, the holy practices, the brahma practices, the heavenly practices, the sick practices, and the infant practices.

If my disciples are able to uphold, recite, copy, and expound the meaning of this sÅ«tra, and are revered, respected, praised, and offered to by sentient beings, then know that at that time the Buddha Dharma has not yet perished.

If the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra is completely circulated, at that time my disciples will often violate the precepts, commit various evils, and will not be able to respectfully believe in this sÅ«tra. Because of their lack of faith, they will not be able to uphold, recite, copy, or explain its meaning. They will not be revered or offered to by the people, and will despise and slander those who uphold it.
'You are the disciples of the six non-Buddhist teachers, not the Buddha's disciples.'
You should know that the Buddha's teachings will not last much longer.
Bodhisattva KÄÅ›yapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
I personally heard the Buddha say that the teachings of KÄÅ›yapa Buddha will remain in the world for seven days before disappearing.
World-Honored One!
Did KÄÅ›yapa TathÄgata have this sÅ«tra?
If he did, why say it will disappear?
If he did not, how can you say that the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra is the secret treasury of all tathÄgatas?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
I previously said that only MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« understands this meaning.
I will now explain it again, listen attentively with utmost sincerity.

The World-Honored Buddhas have two kinds of teachings:
First, worldly teachings; second, the ultimate teachings.

There are two kinds:
The first is external; the second is internal.
External dharmas are subject to destruction, while internal dharmas are not subject to destruction.
There are two kinds:
The first is conditioned; the second is unconditioned.
Conditioned dharmas are subject to destruction, while unconditioned dharmas are not subject to destruction.

The first is that which can be obtained, and the second is that which cannot be obtained.

There are two more kinds:

The eleven types of sutras will perish, but the vaipulya sutras will not perish.

You asked before:
Did Kashyapa Tathagata have this sutra?
